description:
Aeschynomene evenia, commonly known as the sensitive joint vetch, is a species of legume plant that belongs to the genus Aeschynomene. It is native to tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas, particularly in Central and South America.

Aeschynomene evenia is an annual or short-lived perennial herb that typically grows to a height of 30-100 cm. The plant has compound leaves with numerous small, oblong leaflets that are sensitive to touch, closing up when disturbed. The flowers are yellow or reddish-purple, and they produce pod-like fruits that contain several small, flattened seeds.

This species is commonly found in wetlands, such as marshes, swamps, and along the edges of ponds and streams. It is adapted to thrive in wet, humid environments and can tolerate periodic flooding. Aeschynomene evenia is known for its ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen through a symbiotic relationship with rhizobium bacteria, which can help to enrich the soil and support the growth of other plants in its habitat.

The sensitive joint vetch has various ecological and potential economic uses, including as a forage crop, a green manure for soil improvement, and a potential source of natural dyes. Additionally, the plant's distinctive leaf movements and adaptations to aquatic environments make it an interesting subject for botanical and ecological research.
